titleStmt.title: Impact of acute atrial fibrillation termination and prolongation of atrial fibrillation cycle length on the outcome of ablation of persistent atrial fibrillation: A substudy of the STAR AF II trial

affiliation.orgName: for the STAR AF II Investigators
Ospedale S. Maria di Ca' Foncelli
University of Adelaide and Royal Adelaide Hospital

analytic.title: Impact of acute atrial fibrillation termination and prolongation of atrial fibrillation cycle length on the outcome of ablation of persistent atrial fibrillation: A substudy of the STAR AF II trial

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: BACKGROUND Controversy exists about the impact of acute atrial fibrillation (AF) termination and prolongation of atrial fibrillation cycle length (AFCL) during ablation on long-term procedural outcome.

OBJECTIVE The purpose of this study was to analyze the influence of AF termination and AFCL prolongation on freedom from AF in patients from the STAR AF II (Substrate and Trigger Ablation for Reduction of Atrial Fibrillation Trial-Part II) trial.
METHODS Acute changes in AFCL and AF termination were collected during the index procedure of the STAR AF II trial and compared to recurrence of AF at 18 months.
Recurrence was assessed by ECG, Holter (3, 6, 9, 12, 18 months), and weekly transtelephonic ECG monitoring for 18 months.

RESULTS AF terminated in 8% of the pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) arm, 45% in the PVIþcomplex electrogram arm, and 22% of the PVIþlinear ablation arm (P o.001), but freedom from AF did not differ among the 3 groups (P ¼ .15).
Freedom from AF was significantly higher in patients who presented to the laboratory in sinus rhythm (SR) compared to those without AF termination (63% vs 44%, P ¼ .007).
Patients with AF termination had an intermediate outcome (53%) that was not significantly different from those in SR (P ¼ .84)
or those who did not terminate
The original STAR AF II trial was supported by St. Jude Medical.

Address reprint requests and correspondence: Dr. Atul Verma, Southlake Regional Health Centre, 602-581 Davis Dr, Newmarket, Ontario L3Y 2P6, Canada.
E-mail address: atul.verma@utoronto.ca.

Catheter ablation of atrial fibrillation (AF) has become a well-established option for the treatment of symptomatic paroxysmal AF, although success rates of ablation in persistent AF are significantly lower. 1 Complete electrical entrance and exit block from the pulmonary veins (PVs) to the left atrium (LA) is a welldefined and established endpoint of persistent AF ablation. 2
owever, whether ablation of additional targets outside the PVs provides further benefit is unclear.

Prolongation of atrial fibrillation cycle length (AFCL) and acute termination of AF during ablation have been proposed as indicators of successful AF substrate modification and therefore might represent good endpoints for ablation of persistent AF.

7][8][9] For example, the recently published CHASE (Catheter Ablation of Persistent Atrial Fibrillation: Pulmonary Vein Isolation Versus Defragmentation) trial showed that an approach aiming at intraprocedural termination of AF during ablation did not result in better outcome over pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) alone. 10

he STAR AF II (Substrate and Trigger Ablation for Reduction of Atrial Fibrillation Trial-Part II) trial was a large prospective, multicenter trial comparing different approaches to ablation of persistent AF. 11 Together with other procedural parameters, AFCL before and after ablation and termination of AF were prospectively collected.
Therefore, we sought to investigate whether prolongation of AFCL or termination of AF during ablation predicts long-term outcome in the STAR AF II trial.

The data analyzed for this study were prospectively collected as part of a predefined secondary analysis during STAR AF II, which randomized patients with persistent AF to different approaches to AF ablation.
The detailed study protocol has been published previously 11,12 and will be summarized briefly here.
The study was approved by the respective ethics committees at each center.
All patients had persistent AF and were undergoing first-time ablation for AF.
Patients were randomized 1:4:4 to PVI alone, PVI plus ablation of complex fractionated atrial electrograms (CFAEs), or PVI plus linear ablation at the LA roof and mitral isthmus.
Ablation was assisted by a 3dimensional electroanatomic mapping system (EnSite NavX, St. Jude Medical, St. Paul, MN) and performed with an open irrigated radiofrequency energy catheter.
A decapolar catheter was placed into the coronary sinus (CS).

For PVI, wide circumferential isolation of the PVs was performed in all patients, and complete entrance and exit block measured with a circular mapping catheter in the antrum of each PV was the procedural endpoint.
After PVI, patients randomized to additional electrogram ablation underwent mapping of CFAEs using an automated algorithm (EnSite NavX).
During AF, bipolar signals were mapped in the LA, CS, and right atrium, and all areas with a cycle length o120 ms were defined as CFAE.
If a patient was not in AF after PVI, AF was induced by rapid atrial pacing from the CS catheter and assisted with isoproterenol infusion if needed.
Induced AF had to persist for at least 1 minute before CFAE mapping was started.
CFAE ablation was started in the LA and CS and continued until all CFAEs were eliminated or AF terminated.
If AF did not terminate, CFAEs in the right atrium were targeted for ablation.

Intraprocedural antiarrhythmic drugs were not allowed, and all antiarrhythmic drugs were stopped at least 5 half-lives before ablation with the exception of amiodarone, which was stopped at least 8 weeks preablation.
For patients randomized to linear ablation in addition to PVI, an LA roof line and mitral isthmus line was performed.
The endpoint of this approach was complete block across the respective line.
The methods of linear ablation and the endpoints for block were protocol defined. 11
To check whether complete block had been achieved, patients were cardioverted to sinus rhythm (SR) if AF did not terminate during ablation.
If AF terminated into atrial tachycardia or atrial flutter during ablation, the decision to map and ablate the tachycardia or cardiovert was left to the investigator's discretion.
An initial blanking period of 3 months was used, and follow-up visits along with 24 hour Holter recordings were performed 3, 6, 9, 12, and 18 months after the initial ablation procedure.
Weekly transtelephonic monitoring was also performed, with additional recordings in the event of symptoms.
Antiarrhythmic therapy (except amiodarone) was allowed during the first 3 months after initial ablation.
After 3 months, antiarrhythmic therapy had to be stopped to assess for recurrence of AF.
Recurrence of AF was defined as any documented episode of AF 430 seconds.
In case of recurrence of AF after the initial 3-month blanking period, a repeat ablation procedure was allowed by the study protocol using the same approach as in the initial ablation.
Mean AFCL was measured using the CS recording with the shortest average cycle length.
AFCL was measured during a 15-second interval from the same CS recording throughout the procedure to allow for consistent comparison of preablation and postablation values.
Acute procedural AF termination was defined as termination of AF to SR or a regular atrial tachycardia/flutter during the ablation procedure.
Electrical cardioversion of AF during ablation and whether it was performed early during the procedure (during the PVI portion) or at the end were documented.
Analysis of acute AF termination, presence of early SR, and AFCL prolongation were performed using log rank tests with the assistance of Kaplan-Meier curves.
In addition, post hoc pairwise analysis was performed using the Holm method.
Cox proportional regression models were used to perform univariable and multivariable analyses.
Multivariable models were chosen based on the Aikake information criterion combined with the stepwise selection method.
The proportionality assumption was tested.
For covariables that violated the assumption, its interaction with time was added to the model.
Receiver operating curves were analyzed, and the area under the curve was calculated to determine a specific initial AFCL cutoff that predicted 18-month outcome postablation.
A
STAR AF II included a total of 589 patients at 48 experienced centers.
Detailed results from the study's primary outcomes have been published previously. 11
A total of 549 patients underwent ablation with 43-month followup: 61 received PVI alone, 244 received PVI plus CFAE, and 244 received PVI plus linear ablation.

There were no significant differences in any of the assessed baseline characteristics and no significant difference across the 3 treatment arms with regard to the rate of AF recurrence 18 months after a single procedure (41% vs 51% vs 54%, P ¼ .15
for between-group differences). 11

div.head: Influence of AF termination on freedom from AF recurrence

p.s: Of the 549 patients, 73 (13.3%) presented to the laboratory in SR, 143 (26.0%) had acute termination of AF during ablation, and 333 (60.7%) had no acute AF termination.
There was a significant difference in AF termination between randomization arms: 3 (5%) for PVI, 98 (40.2%) for PVI plus CFAE, and 42 (17.2%)
for PVI plus linear ablation (P o.001).
Despite this difference in termination rates between arms, there was no difference in AF recurrence between the arms as described earlier.

Freedom from AF after 1 procedure over follow-up of 18 months was comparable among patients who presented to the laboratory in SR, patients who had acute termination, and those without acute termination (Figure 1).
Patients who began the procedure in SR had a significantly higher freedom from AF compared to patients without AF termination (61.7% vs 42.2%, P ¼ .007).

Patients for whom AF terminated during the procedure had an intermediate outcome, with 52.7% free from AF after 18 months, but this was not significantly different from either of the other 2 groups (P ¼ .92
vs patients not in AF, P ¼ .088
vs patients without AF termination).
When the same comparison was performed only on those patients with acute termination to non-SR, the results were similar.
Among randomization arms, the highest proportion of acute AF termination (40.2%) was seen in the PVI plus CFAE arm.
However, even in this subgroup, there was no difference in freedom from AF between the termination (49.5%) and nontermination (42.7%) groups (P ¼ .40; Figure 2).
Patients who presented to the laboratory in SR had a significantly better outcome (76.1%,
compared to those with or without termination, but the number of patients was small (n ¼ 18).
We then examined the timing of termination during the procedure.

For patients who experienced termination during the PVI component of the ablation, freedom from AF was similar to that of the patients who presented to the laboratory in SR (54.9% vs 48.3% freedom from AF respectively, P ¼ .86),
whereas both groups had significantly better outcome compared to those who did not have AF termination (35.7% freedom from AF, P ¼ .015
vs those presenting in sinus and P ¼ .01
vs those with acute AF termination) (Figure 3).
In those who had termination late in the procedure, there was no difference in outcome in those with and those without AF termination.

div.head: Presence of early SR on freedom from AF recurrence

p.s: Based on the observation of better outcomes in patients who started the procedure in SR, we looked at the early presence of SR either because patients presented to the laboratory in sinus or because sinus was restored early during the procedure by cardioversion during the initial PVI component of the ablation.
Freedom from AF at 18 months was significantly better in patients who had presence of early SR compared to patients without early presence of SR (57.6% vs 41.4%, P o.001; Figure 4).

When the patients with early termination (during PVI) were added to the patients who presented to the laboratory in SR or who were cardioverted back to sinus early in the procedure, they also had a significantly better outcome compared to patients who did not have presence of early SR (56.0%
vs 40.8% freedom from AF, P ¼ .001; Figure 5).

div.head: Predictors of success after AF ablation

p.s: Univariable predictors of long-term success at 18 months after ablation are given in Table 1.
Acute termination of AF during the procedure was a significant predictor in univariable analysis (P ¼ .01).
Presence of early SR was also a significant predictor (P o.001).

Other significant predictors of outcome were AF history ≥2 years, female gender, CHADS 2 score ≥2, LA size 445 mm, age ≥60 years, ejection fraction o55%, and being constantly in AF ≥6 months (Table 1).
During multivariable analysis, AF termination remained a significant predictor of freedom from AF (hazard ratio [HR] 0.606, P ¼ .02),
but the presence of early SR (because the patient arrived in the laboratory in SR or was cardioverted early to sinus) was the strongest predictor for freedom from AF (0.547, P o.001; Table 2).
When presence of early SR was expanded to include patients with early termination to SR, this variable continued to be the strongest predictor of freedom from AF (HR 0.661, P ¼ .001),
whereas AF termination no longer was a significant predictor (HR 0.826, P ¼ .07).

div.head: Influence of AFCL prolongation on freedom from AF recurrence

p.s: Information about AFCL was available in 528 patients.

Prolongation of AFCL by 420 ms during the procedure occurred in 270 patients but had no significant influence on freedom from AF compared to patients without prolongation of AFCL (48% vs 45%, P ¼ .83)
or patients who began the procedure in SR (45% vs 63%, P ¼ 0.06; Figure 6).
The same result was obtained if the cutoff used was 10 or 30 ms.
We performed receiver operator curve analysis on the baseline AFCL at the start of the procedure to determine whether there was a cutoff between those with freedom from AF and those without.
Receiver operator curve analysis failed to identify any significant cutoff that distinguished those with and those without AF recurrence.
This study is one of the largest to investigate the effects of procedural AF termination and AFCL prolongation during ablation of persistent AF based on the outcomes of the STAR AF II study.
AF termination was not a consistent predictor of freedom from AF at 18 months.
Termination rates were significantly different among the 3 arms of the study, yet 18month outcome was similar.
Furthermore, in Kaplan-Meier analyses, those who had acute AF termination did not have significantly better outcomes than did those without.
The presence of SR early in the procedure (either at ablation outset or due to early cardioversion) was the only consistent predictor of better outcome.

AF termination was a univariable and multivariable predictor of freedom from AF but was not as strong a predictor as the presence of early SR and may be driven by early (not late) acute AF terminations, which may be the same as the presence of early SR.
Studies investigating the impact of AF termination on long-term outcome have shown divergent results.
5]13 However, in another study using the stepwise approach, AF termination was not a significant predictor of recurrence-free survival after ablation. 6
Oral et al 9 investigated 100 patients undergoing ablation of complex atrial electrograms and could not find a significant effect of AF termination on outcome.
The CHASE-AF trial randomized 205 patients to ablation with the stepwise approach or PVI alone. 10
Although AF terminated in 60% of the patients undergoing stepwise ablation, recurrence-free survival was no better compared to patients undergoing PVI alone.
Interestingly, in the study by O'Neill et al, 3 AF termination was a predictor of freedom from AF but not a predictor of freedom from atrial tachycardia or all atrial arrhythmias.
There are several possible explanations for the different findings concerning the predictive value of AF termination.
First is the incidence of AF termination found in the study population.

If the rate of AF termination is very low or if it is very high, then it may be impossible to show a significant difference between those with and those without acute termination because of the disparity in numbers between groups.
Furthermore, if both success rates and AF termination rates are either very high or very low, then this may create a statistical association between the 2 variables that cannot be generalized.
Ideally, we need intermediate values of termination and success rate to determine whether there is a true and generalizable association.
In our analysis, success rates at 18 months were approximately 50% and the termination rate overall was 26% (40% in the PVIþCFAE arm), and we did not find a consistent association.
Second, use of antiarrhythmic drugs, especially amiodarone, could influence the probability of AF termination and long-term outcome.

If amiodarone is continued throughout the procedure and afterward or if intravenous antiarrhythmics are used during the procedure, this can contribute to high acute termination rates and better long-term outcome.
In STAR AF II, all antiarrhythmic drugs were stopped at least 5 halflives preablation, and amiodarone was discontinued at least 8 weeks before the procedure.
No intraprocedural antiarrhythmic drugs were allowed.
Third, different studies include different variables into the multivariable models assessing the predictive value of AF termination, which could influence the results of the analysis.
We tried to be inclusive of all relevant variables and also included presence of early SR, which has not been studied extensively before.

It is interesting that the early presence of SR during ablation, because the patient either arrived in the laboratory in SR or was cardioverted early during the procedure, was associated with a significantly better long-term outcome after the procedure.

When included into the multivariable analysis, early SR was also the strongest independent predictor of AF-free survival, possibly because the amplitudes of atrial electrograms are higher during SR and therefore may be more robust to determine ablative endpoints, particularly PVI, in SR vs AF.
In fact, this hypothesis was studied by Bassiouny et al, 14 who compared the results of PVI after early cardioversion to PVI performed during AF with supplementary ablation of CFAE.
In their study, PVI in SR was associated with a significantly better long-term outcome.

It also is possible that patients with persistent AF who are capable of maintaining SR either spontaneously or after early cardioversion represent a population of patients who have less advanced disease.

Thus, those patients who have spontaneous termination during AF ablation, particularly early in the procedure before all the ablation has been completed, may simply represent a phenotype of AF patient who is destined to have a better outcome regardless of the ablative strategy at 18 months compared to those who terminate late or do not terminate at all.

div.head: AFCL prolongation as predictor of outcome

p.s: Prolongation of AFCL during ablation has been proposed as a surrogate for effective AF substrate ablation. 13
AFCL prolongation often precedes AF termination and therefore may predict better long-term outcome.
However, in our investigation, AFCL prolongation by 20 ms was not associated with better long-term outcome after ablation and was not a predictor of AF-free survival in univariable analysis.
Baseline AFCL may distinguish between those patients more likely to have a better postablation outcome and those who are not.
For example, 1 study showed that baseline cycle length 4142 ms may predict those with better outcome compared to those without. 15
In our study, receiver operator curve analysis failed to show any specific cutoff value of initial AFCL that predicted long-term freedom from AF.

The STAR AF II trial was not specifically designed and powered to investigate the influence of AF termination and AFCL prolongation on the outcome of persistent AF ablation, but both parameters were prospectively specified, secondary endpoints.
The results from this investigation only apply to the described methodology for measuring AFCL.

Although this investigation is one of the largest studies investigating the ablation of persistent AF, it still is possible that patient numbers were too small in the subgroups to reveal a significant benefit of AF termination on outcome.
We also did not evaluate a stepwise ablative approach combining PVI plus CFAE ablation plus linear ablation in the STAR AF II trial.
Much of the literature describing AF termination as a predictor of outcome comes from studies using the stepwise approach.

Termination of AF during ablation did not consistently predict long-term outcome of ablation of persistent AF, but the early presence of SR was a consistent and, in fact, the strongest predictor of better freedom from AF. Prolongation of AFCL by ablation had no influence on long-term outcome, and we did not find a specific value of initial AFCL that predicted better outcome.
Figure 1 AF-free survival stratified by intraprocedural AF termination in all arms.
AF ¼ atrial fibrillation.
Figure 2 AF-free survival stratified by intraprocedural AF termination in the pulmonary vein isolation plus complex fractionated atrial electrogram arm.
AF ¼ atrial fibrillation.
Figure3AF-free survival stratified by AF termination status during the PVI part of the procedure.
AF ¼ atrial fibrillation; PVI ¼ pulmonary vein isolation.
Figure 4 AF-free survival of patients with presence of SR during PVI because of spontaneous SR at the beginning of the procedure or cardioversion during PVI.
PVI in or mostly in sinus includes patients who either presented to the laboratory in SR or were cardioverted into SR during PVI.
AF ¼ atrial fibrillation; PVI ¼ pulmonary vein isolation; SR ¼ sinus rhythm.
Figure 5 AF-free survival of patients with presence of SR during PVI because of spontaneous SR at the beginning of the procedure, cardioversion during PVI, or AF termination during PVI.
PVI in or mostly in sinus includes patients who either presented to the laboratory in SR or were cardioverted into SR during PVI or experienced termination of AF during PVI.
AF ¼ atrial fibrillation; PVI ¼ pulmonary vein isolation; SR ¼ sinus rhythm.
Figure6AF-free survival stratified by prolongation of AF cycle length 420 ms.
AF ¼ atrial fibrillation.

Univariable predictors of long-term outcome after one procedure AFCL ¼ atrial fibrillation cycle length; BMI ¼ body mass index; CFAE ¼ complex fractionated atrial electrogram; CI ¼ confidence interval; HR ¼ hazard ratio; LA ¼ left atrium; LVEF ¼ left ventricular ejection fraction; PVI ¼ pulmonary vein isolation.
*Early cardioversion or patient not in AF at start of procedure.
AAD ¼ antiarrhythmic drug; AF ¼ atrial fibrillation;

Predictors of long-term outcome after one procedure in multivariable analysis AF ¼ atrial fibrillation; BMI ¼ body mass index; CI ¼ confidence interval; HR ¼ hazard ratio; LA ¼ left atrium; LVEF ¼ left ventricular ejection fraction.
*Early cardioversion or patient not in AF at start of procedure.
